title: Earthquake shakes mount vernon area
author: Times Stafftimes News Services
text: EARTHQUAKE SHAKES MOUNT VERNON AREA    --  MOUNT VERNON         An earthquake estimated at 3.5 on the Richter scale struck about six miles east of Mount Vernon yesterday afternoon, the University of Washington geophysics department said        The Skagit County Sheriff's Department said there were no reports of injuries or damage from the 5:25 p.m. quake, which was felt in Mount Vernon, about 50 miles north of Seattle.        Jim Zollweg, a geophysicist for the U.S. Geological Survey, said there is usually about one earthquake a year of that magnitude in the Mount Vernon area. He was working in the UW Geophysics Department lab yesterday evening and said there were several calls from people who felt the quake, but no reports of problems.        The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale is capable of causing slight damage.
